>From: "J. B. Rainsberger" 
>I haven't tried that, myself, so I should. Still, if one likes the 
>Whole Value pattern, one prefers to have a Money class [...]

Wholly d'accord with everything said ... except that the name "Money" is a
fatal design blunder (and if I remember correctly, this class name is also
used in the original example of JUnit - if it is so, I hate Kent Beck &
erich Gamma for this). The correct class name would have to be "Amount" or
something ending with "Amount". I have never heard anyone say "Please pay a
money of 12 dollars" ...

... definitely a case which requires a "Renaming" refactoring ...

(... or would you say that I'm nit-picking? I hope not: As I teach all my
students, names are the *only* means of connecting a technical artefact -
e.g. variables, types etc. in software programs - to the reality meant to be
"handled"/"mirrored"/... by the artfact. That's why names have to as good as
possible; and have to be changed if anyone has a problem with a name. That's
why I consider "Rename ..." the most important refactoring by a huge margin
...).

Regards
H.M.M�ller
